chunks.chunk_text: I hate to admit it, but I do sometimes doom scroll. Well, don't feel too bad, Neil, because you're not alone. Research from the University of California found that people all over the world doom scroll, regardless of culture. What's more, there may even be evolutionary reasons why we're attracted to bad news. In this programme, we'll be investigating why we feel compelled to look at and even seek out bad news. And as usual, we'll be learning some
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: new vocabulary as well. But before that, I have a question for you, Neil. Doom scrolling is a very modern idea, which is only possible with the 24-7 non-stop cycle of news reporting. So according to international news agency Reuters, what has been the top global news story of 2023 so far? Is it a. The war in Ukraine b. Increasing prices and inflation or c. Prince Harry's autobiography? I think the answer is an issue that
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: is affecting everyone. Inflation. OK, Neil. I'll reveal the answer at the end of the programme. Now, it might be true that the non-stop news cycle makes doom scrolling possible, but that doesn't explain why we do it. Anthropologist Alaa Alshamahi thinks the answer may lie in human evolution. Here she outlines the problem for BBC Radio 4 programme Why Do We Do That?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: And so many of us do it. Is it a result of 24-7 doom on tap on our phones? Or is it some kind of compulsion that comes from somewhere way, way back?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: But Alaa thinks that's not the whole story. There's another theory. Way back in human history, when we lived in caves, it seemed everything could kill us, from wild animals to eating the wrong mushroom. Knowing what the dangers were and how to avoid them was vital to our survival. And from an evolutionary perspective, survival is everything. As a result, we humans naturally pay attention to the negative
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: stuff – something Alaa calls negativity bias. But while cavemen only knew what was happening in their local area, nowadays we know the bad news from all over the world. Here's Alaa again discussing this with her friend, TV presenter Clara Ampho, for BBC Radio 4 programme Why Do We Do That?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Reading bad news from around the world can depress us and Alaa thinks that the little good
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: doesn't make up for the depressing news. To make up for something means to compensate for something bad with something good.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Maybe it's best to stop doom-scrolling altogether. But with so much bad news pouring into our mobile phones every day, it's not easy. OK, it's time to reveal the answer to my question, Neil. I asked you what news agency Reuters considers the top news story of 2023 so far. And I guessed it was B, inflation. Which was the correct answer. Although there's still plenty of time for 2023 to bring us more doom.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Certainly along with a little positivity too. OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned from this programme about doom-scrolling – spending lots of time reading bad news stories on your phone. Feeling ick is American slang for feeling sick, often because of something disgusting or disturbing. When something is on tap, it's easily available so that you can have as much of it as you want. The phrasal verb to make up for something means to compensate for something bad with something good.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json

chunks.chunk_text: When we romanticise something, we make it sound better than it is. And finally, the saying what doesn't kill you makes you stronger means that by going through difficult life experiences, people build up strength for the future. Once again, our 6 minutes are up. But if doom-scrolling's not for you, remember you can find lots of positive news stories to build your vocabulary here at 6 Minute English.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Doomscrolling_ Why do we do it_.json
